meanings.sent1: He decided to reforge the broken sword into a new, stronger weapon.
meanings.sent2: The blacksmith will reforge the old horseshoe to fit the new horse.
meanings.sent3: After accidentally bending the metal, he had to reforge it into its original shape.
meanings.sent4: She hoped to reforge their friendship after their argument.
meanings.sent5: The artist had to reforge the sculpture after it was damaged in transit.

meanings.definition: To reshape or remold by forging again.
meanings.sent1: The craftsman needed to reforge the metal into a different shape.
meanings.sent2: The jeweler will reforge the gold ring to make it smaller.
meanings.sent3: Trying to reforge the clay vase into a cup resulted in a lopsided creation.
meanings.sent4: She had to reforge her plans after unexpected changes arose.
meanings.sent5: The chef had to reforge the burnt cookies into a new dessert.

meanings.definition: To renew or restore by reworking.
meanings.sent1: The author had to reforge the ending of the story to make it more satisfying.
meanings.sent2: The carpenter will reforge the old table to give it a fresh look.
meanings.sent3: He tried to reforge his reputation by volunteering in the community.
meanings.sent4: The team had to reforge their strategy after losing the first game.
meanings.sent5: She had to reforge her resume to highlight her new skills.
